triples.name: Microbiome
triples.relevance: The paper studies how environmental stress destabilizes microbial communities (microbiomes) and their ecosystem services.

triples.name: Network theory
triples.relevance: The paper analyzes microbial networks using network properties like modularity and cohesion to assess community stability.

triples.name: Modularity (networks)
triples.relevance: Modularity is a key network metric used to measure the compartmentalization of microbial associations.

triples.name: Biodiversity
triples.relevance: The paper measures changes in prokaryotic and fungal diversity along environmental stress gradients.

triples.name: Ecosystem services
triples.relevance: The paper examines how stress-induced microbiome destabilization could undermine ecosystem services provided by soil microbiomes.

triples.name: Pathogen
triples.relevance: The paper tracks changes in pathogenic taxa abundance along stress gradients, finding decreased pathogen relative abundance in high stress.

triples.name: Mutualism (biology)
triples.relevance: The paper observes increased mutualist abundance in high-stress environments, consistent with the Stress Gradient Hypothesis.

triples.name: Oligotroph
triples.relevance: The paper reports increased oligotroph abundance along the stress gradient, suggesting ecological adaptation to nutrient-limited conditions.

triples.name: Stress (biology)
triples.relevance: Environmental stress is the central concept studied, with the paper examining stress impacts on microbial community stability.

triples.name: Stress gradient hypothesis
triples.relevance: The paper uses this ecological theory to explain why microbial negative interactions decrease under environmental stress.

triples.name: Soil microbiology
triples.relevance: The paper analyzes soil microbiomes along elevation and water availability gradients in the Florida scrub ecosystem.

triples.name: Microbial community stability
triples.relevance: The paper proposes that environmental stress destabilizes microbial networks by reducing modularity and negative biotic interactions.
